item.title: 🌅 🎭 Sunrise Theatre Up for Grabs?
item.description: ☀️🌱 Plus: Sticker drop news, weekend events, and a Monday announcement you won’t want to miss.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Friday! Okay, so I know there’s been a huge delay on this — and I apologize for that. I’m just a one-man show, so sometimes things take time. But everything moves in due time.

The good news? The Sunland stickers are finally in. If you filled out the survey and shared the newsletter at least three times, yours will be on the way soon.

Now, that’s the rule — three referrals. But let me be clear: I don’t discriminate. I want everyone to be able to rock a sticker. So once I send them out to those who’ve officially earned them through referrals, I’ll open it up.

If you still want one, all I ask is that you share the newsletter with at least one friend or family member. That’s it. I’m trying to grow this thing organically, with people who actually want to read it and find it meaningful.

So, if you want a sticker and haven’t filled out the form yet, here’s the link:

🔗 Fill out the Sticker Survey

And if not — all good too. Appreciate you either way. Alright…

🌡️ Weather Update: Warm winds and easy skies heading into the weekend

☀️ Day: High of 83°F | 🌤️ Partly cloudy with steady ESE winds at 15–25 mph.
🌙 Night: Low of 72°F | 🌥️ Partly cloudy, with SE winds at 10–20 mph.
🌅 Sunrise: 7:08 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 7:40 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “Can We Talk” by Tevin Campbell 💬🎶

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋 The Main Squeeze
Sunrise Theatre May Soon Have New Management

Did you know the Sunrise Theatre might soon have a new operator?

The City of Fort Pierce has officially received five proposals from outside groups interested in taking over operations of the beloved downtown venue. Right now, the city runs the theater—but officials are hoping a management company can bring long-term stability.

💰 Why Now? The theater has been financially underwater for years. During and after the pandemic, it reportedly lost more than $1 million a year, with the city and federal grants stepping in to keep it afloat. But now that those grants have dried up, city officials say it’s time for a new solution.

🎭 What’s at Stake: This isn’t just any theater. Sunrise has hosted everything from kids’ summer camps and school performances to big-name acts and national tours. It’s a cornerstone of downtown Fort Pierce and a cultural hub with real impact. Even the small black box theater next door plays a role in nurturing the arts locally.

🛠️ What’s Been Done So Far:

  • The Sunrise Theatre Foundation has stepped in to help cut costs.

  • A digital projector was purchased—something many performers now require.

  • But city leaders say a full-time management company may be key to long-term survival.

📅 What’s Next: The city is reviewing the five proposals now but hasn’t said who submitted them or what direction they’re leaning.

👀 What do you think? Should the city hand over operations? Or should it continue managing this cultural staple?
🔗 Leave your thoughts here
📺 Read the Full Story on WPTV

🗞 The Press Round
A few headlines worth knowing about

Vero Beach will host a Jackie Robinson Celebration Game on April 15 at Holman Stadium—located inside the Jackie Robinson Training Complex, a 6,500-seat venue with deep history right in our backyard.

👉 Read More

🌳 Fort Pierce Wants Your Input on Marina Square Park

Planning is underway to redesign Marina Square, and you can help shape it. The city will have a booth downtown tomorrow from 8 AM to 12 PM during the farmers market to gather community feedback on the space.

👉 Take the Survey

🎓 IRSC Launches New Look & Brand Strategy

Indian River State College is rebranding with a new logo and a more “business-like” marketing push to attract Florida students. Big shift in how they present themselves—let me know what you think of the new look.

What A Week!

What a week. We launched the new events site. We dropped the 772Eats local food guide. And—okay, not to toot my own horn—but next week is shaping up to be even better. 📣 Big announcement Monday.📣 Another one Tuesday.📣 And a final one Thursday. For now, I just want to say thank you. If there’s ever anything I can do for you, reply to this email or hit me up.

See you Monday! With Love…

Ja’Min

item.title: 🎭 A Local Stage, A Big Story
item.description: Lindsay School of the Arts puts on a beautiful production of a play titled, "On My Own" right in the heart of Fort Pierce!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
A Local Stage, A Big Story

So I want to tell you about this show I saw last week—but also the school behind it.

Let’s talk about Lindsay School of the Arts. I first heard of LSA a couple years ago when my friend Kay invited me to an art showcase there. It was simple, but special—artwork from students lining the walls, families walking the halls, and an energy that just made you pause. Ever since, I’ve kept my eye on what they’re doing.

Fast forward to this month—I was at Cool Beans Brew, my favorite coffee shop in Fort Pierce (hands down), and I kept seeing these posters for a student-led show called “On My Own.” Turns out, the team at Lindsay had been working on this musical since last summer, and everything—from the story, to the choreography, to the music—was created by the students themselves.

That alone is impressive. But what really struck me was the space.

LSA recently moved from their cozy Orange Ave location (yes, the one with the peacocks crossing the road) to a bigger building on Avenue A, where they’ve built out a full black box theater and designed a real arts campus from the ground up.

💬 Why It Matters: These kids aren’t just learning about art—they’re creating it, producing it, and putting it on stage. The show was emotional, intense, and reflective of what young people are really thinking about today. It’s hard to put into words, but the message from the show has stuck with me (no spoilers incase they put it on again).

🎟️ If you ever see an event, showcase, or open mic hosted by LSA—go.📍And shoutout to Cool Beans for always being a creative hub in the heart of Fort Pierce.

This is the kind of local magic worth supporting.


Powered by beehiiv

item.title: 🌅 🚗 Parking’s Not Free Much Longer
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: Also inside: PSL’s roundabout debate, Vero’s audit scramble, and a jazz brunch that sold out.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Wednesday!  And that means two things:

1️⃣ My weekly reminder to share this newsletter with just one friend
2️⃣ A big thank you for being here

Between launching the events page and 772Eats, a lot of new folks have been finding their way into the Sunland world—and getting real value out of it. That means the world to me. If you’ve got any thoughts, feedback, or ideas for what would make this even better, I’m always open. I like building things people actually need—not just more noise.

Alright…

Question❓Did you fall for any April Fools jokes yesterday? I completely missed it (again 😭). Pretty sure I’ve forgotten about April 1st five years in a row now…

🌡️ Weather Update: Humid, breezy, and warming up quick

☀️ Day: High of 83°F | ⛅ Cloudy early, then partly sunny by the afternoon
🌙 Night: Low of 74°F | 🌙 Mainly clear with ESE winds at 10–20 mph.
🌅 Sunrise: 7:10 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 7:39 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “Ascension (Don’t Ever Wonder)” by Maxwell 🌬️💫

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋🍋 The Main Squeeze
Fort Pierce to End Free Beach Parking by Year’s End

This might be your last summer of free parking at Jetty Park.

Fort Pierce is moving forward with a plan to install paid parking at Jetty Park, Jaycee Park, and South Causeway Park before the end of the year. The city says it spends around $300K annually maintaining these spots, and parking fees would help cover beach upkeep, safety, and infrastructure.

💬 Why It Matters: Here’s where things get tricky. While the official line is that the money will go toward maintenance, some folks inside City Hall are concerned that those funds won’t actually go back into the parks—or the Jetty area at all. Instead, there’s talk it could end up in the general fund, where it’s harder to track and could get used for totally unrelated projects.

Plus, there’s still the big question:

Should locals have to pay? Some say absolutely not—residents already support the city through taxes. Others argue a yearly pass is fair, as long as the money actually goes back to the beaches.

👀 What We Know So Far:

  • Rates may be $3/hr, $20/day, or $60/year

  • The city is finalizing a contract with a private vendor

  • The commission is expected to vote next month

  • Other beach sites aren’t included (for now)

🗣️ Over to you: Do you think locals should be exempt? Should the money go directly back into the beach area? Why do you think this is really happening?

Leave your thoughts here.

🍊 The Press Round
ROUND AND ROUND WE GO

📉 Vero’s Still in Hot Water Over Missing Audit

Vero Beach met with Sen. Jay Collins about getting more time to file its overdue audit—and maybe avoid losing $258K in state funds. They say it’ll be done by April 30, but after months of financial mismanagement, a lot of folks aren’t buying it.

👉 Catch Up Here

🚗 PSL Isn’t Sold on Roundabouts

The city’s looking to add two roundabouts on Paar Drive, but some residents say they’d rather have traffic lights. Crashes are up in the area, but locals aren’t convinced roundabouts are the fix.

👉 See the Debate

🤰 Martin’s Maternity Clinic Just Closed

Cleveland Clinic North in Stuart shut down its labor & delivery unit this week. Now, moms may have to drive 20+ miles to Tradition to give birth. A nonprofit hopes to open a local maternity center—but it’s still in early talks.

👉 Read the Full Story

3 Local Headlines for the Road!

    Fort Pierce secured another $10M to relocate its wastewater plant—totaling nearly $70M in state funding so far.

    👉 Read more

  2. 🏢 Means Court Lease Controversy

    City paid $100K+ in bills despite lease terms. Officials now calling for stronger oversight of public property deals.

    👉 Read more

    Hourly rainfall is intensifying in nearly 90% of U.S. cities—raising flood risks and storm costs.

📸 This is Sunland
Heavenly Birthday!

Man, every time I look up, I can’t help but remember my uncle. Sometimes, I feel a deep sense of sadness, but mostly, I feel a reason to celebrate his life. Today is the birthday of a legend, and the reason Sunland News exists! We hope to continue his legacy and keep pushing Sunland to new heights. Long live Slate Rock!

See you tomorrow!
With Love, Ja’Min

item.content:encoded:
Good Afternoon, Sunland

It’s Tuesday! I spend a lot of time driving around—which means I also spend a lot of time sitting at stoplights (😭). And one thing I always notice? Those painted utility boxes. I’ve never seen one that wasn’t interesting.

Well, turns out there’s an open call for artists right now in Port St. Lucie to design new ones. Anyone can apply (yes, even you), and the deadline is April 7. 🎨 Submit your design here. Alright…

🗣 Survey Says: St. Lucie Schools wants feedback from parents—it’s quick and actually helps shape what comes next. 📋 Take the Family Survey

🍽 I got tired of esting fast food and digging for local restaurants So I built 772Eats.com—a clean, no-fluff list of local restaurants (no chains). You can search, filter, and even keep notes on spots you’ve tried. I’d love your feedback if you check it out! 🔗 Explore 772Eats.com.

🚗 Question: Do you find yourself going to Indian River County or Martin County more often?

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

Check out the Sunland Events website here for more events happening…
If you have an event, send it to me here

🏄‍♂️ Refill
A Surf Park Rises on Midway Road 💸

I heard a phrase once: “If you live long enough, you live twice.” That feels true for this one.

If you’ve been around since 2020, you probably remember whispers of a surf park coming to Fort Pierce. It sounded big, maybe too big. But now—out past the cattle fields on Midway Road—it looks like it’s really happening.

🏄🏻 Catch Up Quick: Koa Bay, a nearly $600 million surf park community, is officially underway. Set across 204 acres, the project promises 450 waves an hour, 1,100 homes, hotels, shops, yoga studios, co-working spaces, and even the world’s first floating surf pool.

Developers say the surf lagoon will offer real waves up to 7 feet tall, with zones for beginners and experienced surfers. The site is still largely hidden by tree coverage, but officials confirm that ground has been broken.

The project was approved by Fort Pierce commissioners in 2022. It’s expected to bring jobs, tourism, and new housing to the area.

💰 The Cost: Sessions are expected to cost $80, with residential memberships starting at $11,250 plus a $45,000 initiation fee.

Construction is ongoing, with residential phases expected to wrap by the end of 2026.

What do you think? Is this needed here in the County?
Leave your thoughts here → Submit a response

item.title: 🌅 🥕 Tradition Market Is Winning the Weekend
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: 5 new restaurants on Gatlin, Market showdowns, and fire risks—here’s what’s happening.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Monday… And it’s the last day of March. Q1 is officially over. And to me, this part of the year always feels a little slow. But before we know it, summer will be here.

🚨 Big News: I made some pretty major upgrades over the weekend to the Sunland Events site. You can now:

  • Filter by event type

  • Save events into a clipboard

  • Click to open directions in Google Maps

If you find it helpful, share it with a friend. I’m really trying to make this the best event board in the county.

✨ Also Cool: The City of PSL is offering free tax help for anyone making under $67K a year. Details here.

🌡️ Weather Update: Hot, humid, and a little stormy to close out March

☀️ Day: High of 85°F | ⛅ A mix of sun and clouds with a 30% chance of a thunderstorm.🌙 Night: Low of 67°F | 🌤️ Partly cloudy
🌅 Sunrise: 7:12 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 7:38 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “Sunshine” by Mos Def ☀️🎶

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋 The Main Squeeze:
🍇 Market Wars

Okay, so I’ve been watching this for a minute now—and I think it’s time we officially talk about it.

Let’s call it what it is: Market Wars (jokingly of course).

Every weekend, different parts of the county are trying to be the go-to for fresh food, handmade goods, and that weekend crowd.

You’ve got the Fort Pierce market downtown on Saturdays (split between food and artisan), the MidFlorida Event Center market in PSL, the one over in St. Lucie West every other week… but then there’s the Tradition Market.

And honestly? It’s in another league.

✍️ The Rebrand: Now rebranded as the Neighborhood Farmers’ Market at Tradition Square, this thing is packed every Sunday from 9 to 2. Katherine Castillo, who runs it, also opened a full-on Market Store last year—so vendors can sell during the week too.

And just last week, they announced a new partnership with WPBF 25, making the station the exclusive TV sponsor. That kind of exposure doesn’t just happen. It’s a huge boost for local vendors, and a sign this market is growing in a serious way.

💬 Why It Matters: These markets aren’t just little weekend hangouts. They’re driving real traffic and money to small businesses. Booths go for $60–$80, and hundreds of people come out to shop, eat, and support local.

👀 Been to Tradition Market lately? Think another one’s better?

🗳 Drop your pick here → Tell me what you think
📍 Or catch them live every Sunday at Tradition Square.

🍊 The Press Round: New Strip! New Name! New Worries!

🌱 Thrive IRC: New Name, Same Mission

Formerly the Substance Awareness Center, Thrive IRC is expanding its impact with a new name, new space, and the same commitment to healing.

🍽️ 5 New Spots Hit Gatlin Blvd. in PSL

👉 Read More

A 188-acre fire near Palm City is fully contained, but dry weather and wind have residents—and firefighters—on alert for flare-ups.

👉 Read More

🍋 Refill: Fatal Brightline Crash in Downtown Fort Pierce

A man was killed Thursday night after being hit by a Brightline train in downtown Fort Pierce, near Avenue A and Depot Drive. Police say the train was headed north, sounded multiple horns, and still made impact. His name has not yet been released.

It’s the latest in a string of Brightline-related fatalities on the Treasure Coast, including recent incidents in Vero Beach, Jensen Beach, and Stuart.

At the same time, Brightline is planning a $60 million station in Stuart—though local officials there are now clashing over the deal. Some have floated Fort Pierce as an alternative station location.

💬 Why It Matters: As the region considers expansion, safety is still a major concern. High-speed trains require high-level infrastructure—and recent incidents have sparked new questions about how ready the area really is.

item.title: 🌅🏢 Fort Pierce Pays $103K for an Empty Building
item.description: ☀️🌱 Plus: A new restaurant game, top events, Costco gas opens early, and more.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Friday! First week back after the break has been a good one. I’ve been working on a lot behind the scenes to make the newsletter better. Huge thanks to everyone who shared feedback on the events page—improvements are on the way.

Also, I’ve been building something fun: a little “What Should I Eat?” game Watch the video here. As someone who constantly struggles to find new spots, this is something I’d actually use.

I’ve also been thinking about putting together a full guide to local restaurants. Would that be helpful? Just hit reply and let me know what you think.

Ja’Min Devon

Sponsored ⚕️: Say Hi Again to
Amandla Wellness 

⏳ How long does your doctor really spend with you?

The average doctor’s visit lasts just 18 minutes—barely enough time to scratch the surface of your health concerns.

At Amandla Wellness Center, Dr. Margaret Lott does things differently. She spends a full hour with each patient, ensuring you feel heard, understood, and truly cared for. This isn’t rushed medicine. It’s personalized wellness, tailored to you.

💙 Real time. Real care. Real results.

📍Check out Amandla Wellness Center Schedule a consultation today here

🍋 The Main Squeeze: $103K and Counting? Fort Pierce Still Paying for Empty INC Building

Here’s a story that had me going: wait, what?

Back in 2021, the City of Fort Pierce leased the historic Means Court building to a nonprofit called Incubate Neighborhood Center (INC) for $12 a year. The goal? To turn the space into an incubation hub for local businesses, complete with entrepreneurship training, a kitchen incubator, and more—right in the heart of Lincoln Park.

But today, that building is still closed. And now, a Hometown News investigation reveals Fort Pierce taxpayers have footed over $100,000 in expenses—utilities, mowing, fire monitoring—even though the lease clearly says those costs were supposed to be paid by INC.

The building? Still not open. It’s actually been labeled “unlawful” for occupancy since February 2023. And even while closed, utility bills paid by the city reportedly ranged from $1,300 to $1,800 a month. 🤯

INC’s CEO Canieria Gardner says the city told her they’d handle the utilities “despite the lease,” but no one from the city has confirmed who authorized it. Meanwhile, the nonprofit is leasing the $1 million property for $12 a year, with a written promise to take on all financial responsibility.

💬 Why It Matters: This one raises more questions than answers. From lease terms to funding promises, it spotlights deeper concerns around transparency and oversight—especially for a building many hoped would serve as a cornerstone of community and economic growth.

👉 Read the full investigation by Hometown News—it’s worth your time.

🔗 Read the Full Story

item.title: 🌅 🎨 Fort Pierce’s Highwaymen Museum Could Be Expanding
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: New homes, new schools, and maybe a bigger museum? Here’s what’s happening in Fort Pierce.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Wednesday! And this newsletter serves as my weekly reminder to share it with a friend! I appreciate everyone who continues to share it and contributes to building a community around sharing. If you want a quick how to on how to use your referral link, just trply to this email. Alright…

🎵 Sounds like: “Forget Me Nots”

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋 The Main Squeeze:
Expanding the Highwaymen Museum
Fort Pierce Eyes Key Property Acquisition

TL;DR: Fort Pierce officials are considering purchasing a property next to the Highwaymen Museum, potentially expanding its footprint and further cementing Avenue D as a cultural landmark. With over $911,000 already invested in renovations, city leaders are now looking at additional funding sources to complete upgrades and possibly acquire the neighboring building.

💰 The Investment So Far: The museum, housed in the city-owned Jackie L. Caynon Sr. Building, has already seen significant progress. With over $911,000 spent on renovations—including $483,000 in state funding and $400,000 from the FPRA—final structural work is expected to wrap up this month.

🏛️ Why It Matters:

  • The Highwaymen Museum is a cornerstone of Avenue D’s revitalization and a key tourism driver for Fort Pierce.

  • The museum will honor the legacy of the legendary African American artists who gained fame for their vibrant Florida landscape paintings.

  • City leaders see an opportunity to expand the museum’s footprint by purchasing an adjacent property, ensuring the surrounding area reflects the investment made in the museum itself.

💬 The Discussion:

Board members, including Commissioner James Taylor, suggested tapping into $2 million in available county tourism funds to cover outstanding change-orders and explore property acquisition. However, the city is still waiting on formal guidance from the county’s tourism director.

🚧 Next Steps:

  • City officials are exploring how to secure additional funding for museum improvements.

  • They will investigate purchasing the neighboring building, which is currently for sale, to expand the museum’s footprint.

  • If urgent decisions are needed, FPRA Chairwoman Linda Hudson said a special meeting could be called before April.

👉 The Highwaymen Museum has been years in the making, and now, Fort Pierce leaders are looking to ensure it’s as impactful as possible. Do you think the city should invest in expanding the museum? Drop your thoughts here!

🍊 The Press Round: ⚾️ Jackie Robinson Celebration

⚾ Jackie Robinson Celebration Game Returns to Vero Beach

After a five-year hiatus, the Jackie Robinson Celebration Game is back at the Jackie Robinson Training Complex on April 15—honoring the baseball legend who broke the sport’s color barrier. The Clearwater Threshers and West Palm Beach Cardinals will face off, with gates opening at 5 p.m. and the game starting at 6:45 p.m. Proceeds benefit the United Way of Indian River County.

👉 Get Tickets Here

🛍️ Fort Pierce’s Iconic African Art Store Closing This Month

The beloved African Art, Antiques and Gifts shop at Kraaz Square in downtown Fort Pierce is closing March 31 after its lease was not renewed.

  • Owner Ndiaga Niang, known for his warm “Welcome to Africa” greeting, has been a tenant for seven years.

  • The shop sells home decor, jewelry, clothes, and African imports.

  • A restaurant is planned for the space, though no tenant has been finalized.

Niang is packing up late into the night but remains hopeful for the future: “God knows better.” He plans to relocate but hasn’t announced where yet.

👉 Full Story

🏫 New Schools Coming as St. Lucie County Grows Fast

With 1,500 new students enrolling each year, St. Lucie Public Schools are expanding to keep up.

  • Western Grove K-8 ($70M) set to open in 2026.

  • Legacy High School opens this fall, capping enrollment at 1,600 students its first year.

  • Fort Pierce Westwood is getting a full rebuild, opening after winter break next year.

👉 Full Story

item.title: 🌅🚀 New Sunland Events Site is LIVE!
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: A 5K, a legacy, and a lesson in community—this one was personal.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Afternoon, Sunland

It’s Tuesday! And I’ve got something for you.

It’s still in beta, but I promise—this will be the best local events site we’ve had. Right now, if you visit events.sunland.news, you’ll see the early version of a local events website I’ve been building over the last week.

It’s simple and straightforward for now, but the goal is to keep it packed with everything happening locally. And since I built this from scratch, I can take it as far as I want.

Thinking about adding:
📲 Text reminders for upcoming events
🔖 Save events to your profile
📩 Get email/text alerts so you never miss them

Check it out, let me know what you think I should add here, and stay tuned for what’s next!

📢 Shout-out: Shoutout to a kind Redditor who put me on to this—Everbridge, a site where you can opt in for real-time safety alerts from local agencies. We’re talking emergency notifications, road closures, weather updates—the stuff you actually want to know about. Check it out and stay in the loop! Sign up here.

🚗 Trivia Time: What’s the farthest you’d be willing to drive for a weekend event?

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋 The Main Squeeze: 🏃‍♂️ Running for a Legacy

TL;DR: The Slate Rocks 5K took place on March 15, and I finally get to write about it. This wasn’t just any race—it was a community-driven event in honor of my late uncle, Darin Slater (aka Slate Rock), who we lost to colon cancer over a year ago. Seeing the love, support, and turnout for this event was a reminder of why community matters—and why his legacy continues to inspire.

Saturday, March 15, started early, but the energy at the Slate Rocks 5K was unmatched. Friends, family, and the Westwood High Class of ‘89 came out strong. Commissioner Arnold Gaines was in the crowd. And at the heart of it all? Slate’s Angels—Iman, Tori, Riley, and Reagan— who put this event together to honor their father and raise awareness for colon cancer.

For me, this run was personal. My uncle Slate Rock wasn’t just my uncle—he was a pillar of the community, a mentor, and one of the biggest reasons Sunland News even exists. He taught me early on that community isn’t just something you live in—it’s something you build. And this event? It was a perfect reflection of that.

💙 March is Colon Cancer Awareness Month, but taking care of your health isn’t just a one-month thing. I’m grateful we were able to share resources and bring attention to something so important. And I can’t wait to see this 5K grow into something even bigger in the years to come.

🙏 A massive thank you to everyone who showed up, supported, and donated. You made this event special.

👕 Still want a Slate Rocks 5K shirt? We’ve got a few left! Grab yours here.
📺 Watch the commercial we made for the 5K

🥳 What’s Happening: 8 Out of Town Events

I’ve been getting requests to cover events happening just outside the county, so starting today, I’ll be adding a few each Tuesday that might be worth checking out. Let me know if there’s one you think should make the list!

Friday, March 28

🎭 Back In the Building: The Ultimate Elvis Tribute Musical – Celebrate Elvis’ 90th birthday with a high-energy tribute featuring jumpsuits, leather, and swiveling hips at the King Center for the Performing Arts. | 8 PM | Details

🎨 Art After Dark at the Norton Museum of Art – Experience live music, performances, art workshops, and reduced admission at the Norton Museum’s weekly after-dark event. | 5 PM–10 PM | Details

🎶 FREE! Downtown Beach Bash Dance Party with Riptide – Enjoy live music, food trucks, and vendors at this beachside dance party in Downtown Vero Beach. | 6 PM–9 PM | Free | Details

📖 Tell HER Story: Celebrating National Women’s Month – A night of networking, storytelling with author Christella François, and a vision board party at Rosalind’s Uptown Fitness. | 6 PM–9 PM | RSVP Here

Saturday, March 29

🎨 Melbourne, FL Spring Art & Craft Expo – Browse 300 booths filled with arts, crafts, and creativity at Wickham Park in Melbourne. Free admission & parking. | 10 AM–5 PM | Free | Details

🛍️ Spring Craft Fair – Shop for unique handmade goods and sweet treats at the South Florida Fairgrounds in West Palm Beach. | 10 AM–4 PM | Free | Details

🎶 Dirty River Jam 2025 – An all-day festival with live bands, food, and drinks, benefiting the Environmental Studies Council at Tako Tiki Jensen Beach. | 11 AM–11 PM | $5 | Details

🎸 Punk Show! – A raw and energetic night featuring SiKE!, Goat Rope, and Constant Throw at The Stamp Bar in Vero Beach. | 9 PM | Ages 21+ | $5 | Details

If you have an event, send it to me here

🍹The Refill: Cafe 772 Review

I finally tried Cafe 772 in Fort Pierce, and I gotta be honest—it was amazing. If you’re not familiar, they recently opened a new spot in Fort Pierce, right off Orange Avenue in the Senoko Plaza, and they’re bringing serious heat to the local food scene.

I went last week and had their carne asada tacos. First impression? Incredible. The flavors were on point, the corn tortillas hit just right, and the quality was undeniable.

Now, I won’t lie—a little pricier than their counterparts . And anybody who knows me knows my go-to spot is Super Taqueria on US1 in Fort Pierce. Nothing against the other locations or taco joints, but that’s my place. If you’re ever looking for me and I owe you something, I’m probably at Super Taqueria—come find me. 😂 

Final Verdict: 8.5/10—great tacos, great spot, definitely one to watch.

Tried Cafe 772 yet? Let me know what you think! Check out the menu here.

🥛 Last Drop: Around the State in a day
3 Headlines For The Road!

  2. 🤧 Allergy Season Getting Longer

    If your allergies feel worse each year, it’s not just you. Climate change is extending allergy season across major U.S. cities, making symptoms last longer. Check the data

  3. 💸 Fraud Cases Surge in Florida

    Floridians lost over $12.5 billion to scams last year—a 25% spike from 2023. Miami ranks among the worst-hit areas for fraud and identity theft. See the report

item.title: 🌅 Sunland Returns + Fort Pierce Names New Leader
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: Catch up on Fort Pierce’s new manager, Brightline tensions, and summer camp changes.
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Monday—and I’m back!

First off, thank you for all the birthday love and the replies to last week’s email (and the Sunland Instagram too). I feel rejuvenated and ready to take Sunland News to a whole new level. That said… I couldn’t sit still during my break. I’ve been working on two projects I’m really excited about—both of which folks have been asking for.

Come back tomorrow for a first look at one of them. Can’t wait to show you.

🌮 Want to Try: Tacos Ponchos just opened in PSL and they’re already bringing the fiesta vibes. Tacos, family, and flavor—looks like it’s worth a shot.

🪑 Board Seat Open: Fort Pierce is looking for residents to join the Infrastructure Surtax Citizen Oversight Committee—help guide how public funds get spent on local projects. Apply by April 17.

🌡️ Weather Update: Warm and breezy with clouds rolling in tonight

☀️ Day: High of 84°F | 🌤️ Sun and clouds mixed
🌙 Night: Low of 64°F | ☁️ Cloudy skies
🌅 Sunrise: 7:20 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 7:35 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “Love Come Down”

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋 The Main Squeeze:
Richard Chess, Fort Pierce City Manager Is Officially In

TL;DR: After months of debate—and some heated back-and-forth over salary—Fort Pierce officially has a new city manager. Richard Chess will take the reins on April 2 at a starting salary of $200,000, closing the chapter on a seven-month search that began after the arrest of former manager Nick Mimms.

📉 Salary Compromise: Chess initially asked for $235K—$20K more than his current Broward County salary. Commissioners pushed back hard, drawing a firm line at $200K. After negotiations, Chess agreed to take the pay cut. If his six-month performance review goes well, he’ll receive a 5% raise.

🗣️ Behind the Scenes: A source within the city told Sunland News that negotiating the contract so publicly was “not typical practice,” but said there’s a sense of relief now that the search is over.

📝 Contract Notes:

  • 5-year term, then switches to year-to-year

  • Can be fired without cause (with severance)

  • $10K relocation stipend

  • No automatic seat on the FPRA board (unlike his predecessor)

💬 Why It Matters: After Mimms’ arrest last year over bid tampering allegations, commissioners were careful with this hire. Some, like Commissioner Broderick, still have reservations, calling the move a “stepping stone.” Others say Chess is ready to commit and bring stability to a city in transition.

📅 What’s Next: Chess officially starts April 2. His first six months will be critical—not just for him, but for how Fort Pierce defines leadership and accountability moving forward.

💭 What are your thoughts on the city manager decision? Should Fort Pierce have offered more—or less? Drop your take here. Drop your thoughts here!

🍊 The Press Round: Dry Season!

🚉 No Deal Yet on Brightline Station Support from Stuart

Martin County has paused efforts to get Stuart’s formal backing for grant funding to build a Brightline station downtown. A meeting between city and county officials ended in a stalemate, with Stuart leaders saying they won’t support the plan unless Brightline chips in financially. County officials say the delay could hurt their chances at securing federal grants.

👉 Read More

🎒 Port St. Lucie Expands Summer Camps, Adds Lottery System

The City of Port St. Lucie is adding four new locations for its popular summer youth camps, running June 9–Aug. 1. A new lottery system will give families registering for all eight weeks an equal shot at enrollment. Registration is open March 14–28.

👉 Details Here

🔥 Brush Fire Forces Evacuations Near Vero Beach

Two wildfires burned 38 acres and forced five home evacuations west of Vero Beach on Saturday. No injuries or damage reported, but roads near 65th Street and 58th Avenue were closed as crews worked to contain the blaze.

👉 Full Story

Join the Mission and support Sunland News and help fuel the goal of delivering smarter, faster very, very local news that keeps you informed on what’s unfolding here.

💡 Why it matters: Your support allows me to keep St. Lucie County informed and engaged through the daily Sunland News newsletter—and sets the stage for tackling bigger, in-depth reporting projects in the near future.

🎁 What’s in it for you: Exclusive updates, behind-the-scenes insights, and other perks as we grow (bookstore and otherwise) this community together.

Slate Rock’s 5K

Something I learned on my break is just how important Sunland is and can be. A lot of people told me how much they missed the newsletter, and how it helps them navigate the city and county at large! It’s a long journey but a worthwhile one! This is the beginning of the beginning.

See you tomorrow!
With Love, Ja’Min

item.title: 🌅 💰 Fort Pierce’s Paid Parking Update + St. Lucie’s High Taxes Explained!
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: Local jobs, PSL’s tax dilemma & weekend events to check out!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Friday! And it’s my last newsletter until March 24th. My birthday is on Monday, March 17th, so as a gift to myself, I’m taking a bit of a break.

I’ve been writing this newsletter for the last nine months and haven’t missed a day (outside of holidays), so a little reset wouldn’t hurt. While I won’t be writing every day, I’ll be using this time to catch up on some projects for the newsletter and come back strong—ready to keep growing and keeping everyone informed in St. Lucie County.

Thank you for being here! Alright…

🌴 Want to Try? R&S Patties – Jamaican beef patties, coco bread, oxtail, curry goat, jerk chicken, and more. Looks like it’s worth a shot!

🌡️ Weather Update: A golden day with a full moon glow 🌕

☀️ Day: High of 79°F | ⛅ Sunshine and clouds mixed,
🌙 Night: Low of 67°F | 🌤️ Partly cloudy
🌅 Sunrise: 7:31 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 7:29 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “Moonbeam Levels” by Prince 🌙💜

Ja’Min Devon

🍋 The Main Squeeze: Parking Continued…

Catch Up: The City of Fort Pierce has officially responded to community concerns about its plan to introduce paid parking at Jetty Park, Jaycee Park, and South Causeway Park. Their latest statement emphasizes that this pilot program is meant to fund park maintenance, beach improvements, and public safety.

What the City is Saying:

  • 💰 Paid parking revenue will go toward park upkeep, infrastructure, and beach maintenance.

  • 🚗 The move is also meant to increase parking turnover on South Hutchinson Island, where businesses have raised concerns about limited availability.

  • 🏖️ The city acknowledges the backlash and says it’s working to implement the plan with residents’ best interests in mind.

But Here’s the Issue:

Locals aren’t sold. Many feel they shouldn’t have to pay for parking at their own parks—especially when they’re already paying taxes.

💬 What Some of You Are Saying:

  • “FREE for locals!!!”

  • “We already pay for cops. Why can’t they enforce parking instead?”

  • “If I have to pay for parking, I’m hanging up my volunteer T-shirt.”

What’s Next: The final contract with PCI Municipal Services is still in the works, but it’s clear the city has a communications battle ahead.

🍊 The Press Round: $15 Parking

🏗️ New $40M Business Park Approved in Stuart

Stuart City Commission unanimously approved the Baron Business Park project on Willoughby Blvd, bringing 135 units for small businesses and a new traffic signal near Martin County High School. Construction is set to begin this summer and finish in 18 months.

👉 Read more

📈 St. Lucie County Has the Highest Property Tax Rate in Florida

St. Lucie County homeowners are paying the highest property tax rate in the state, according to Florida TaxWatch. While the average tax bill is around $2,000, residents say the financial burden is growing. County officials link the high millage rate to lower home values compared to wealthier counties.

👉 Read More

🏠 St. Lucie County Opens Public Housing Waitlist—But Not Section 8

For the first time since June 2022, St. Lucie County’s public housing waitlist is open until April 10. However, Section 8 (Housing Choice Vouchers) remains closed. The average wait time for public housing here is 48 months, with 774 families currently living in public housing across Martin and St. Lucie counties.

👉 Read more

🎉 Top Events: The Top Clicked Events This Week

Saturday, March 15

  • 🏃‍♂️ Slate Rock’s 5K – Honor Darin Slater’s legacy with this meaningful run spreading awareness for Colon Cancer. | 7:30 AM–11 AM | Register Online

  • 🎨 Peacock Arts Market – A weekend-long event showcasing local artists and vendors. | 9 AM–3 PM (March 15-16)

  • 🎥 Saturday Drive-In Movie Night: Transformers ONE – Watch the latest Transformers movie under the stars. | 7:45 PM | Tickets Required

Sunday, March 16

  • 🐾 St. Patty’s Celebration Pot O’ Gold & Pet Parade – A fun-filled market with a pet parade, pony rides, live music, and a karaoke session. | 9 AM–2 PM

Monday, March 17

  • 🔍 St. Patty’s Pot of Gold Search at SusieDoos’ Playhouse – A fun gold coin hunt for kids with special prizes. | 10 AM–12 PM

If you have an event, send it to me here

💧 The Last Drop: 3 Things For The Road!

  1. 🏓 Fort Pierce Adds 4 New Pickleball Courts at Pinewood Park

    Pinewood Park is back open after an $83K renovation, featuring new pickleball courts, a resurfaced tennis court, and upgraded playground equipment. Some locals are still pushing for a name change to honor Bonny Dunn. 👉 Read more

  2. 📢 Fort Pierce is Hiring!

    The City of Fort Pierce is looking to fill multiple positions, including Administrative Assistant, Project Engineer, and more. If you’re looking for a local job 👉 Apply here: Link

  3. 📈 Florida Ranks No. 1 for Business Relocations

    Florida led the nation in business moves for the 30th year, gaining 503 new businesses in 2023 and seeing a surge in startups. 👉 More details

📸 This is Sunland: See You Soon!

I’m not sure why I’m feeling so reflective about taking this break, but the words I write here don’t quite do justice to how grateful I feel to create this newsletter. I love improving it slowly but surely, and I appreciate you all for being on this journey with me.

See you soon! With love,
Ja’Min

Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Wednesday! And I first want to thank everyone that has been sharing the newsletter! The referrals recently have been going up in a really nig way! Every little bit helps! I’ll take this time to remind you if you know of anyone that could benefit from staying up to date with what’s haooening locally, consider sharing this newsletter with them! Alright…

🏆 Shoutout to IRSC Swimming & Diving! 51 straight titles for the men. 47 for the women. Pure dominance. Huge congrats to Indian River State College for once again being crowned NJCAA National Champions! A legacy of dedication, drive, and excellence—both in and out of the water.

🍗 Meal Deal: It’s $10 dinner day at Stoney’s BBQ! Grab a chicken or rib dinner for 2012 prices. Ha! Tell them Sunland sent you! (*Sponsored Post)

🌙 Night: Low of 56°F | 🌙 Clear skies
🌅 Sunrise: 7:33 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 7:28 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “Brighter Day” by Kirk Franklin ☀️🎶

Ja’Min Devon

🍋 The Main Squeeze: Fort Pierce Moves Closer to Paid Parking at Three City Parks

Catch Up: Fort Pierce is moving forward with a paid parking plan for Jetty Park, Jaycee Park, and South Causeway Park to help cover park maintenance costs. Originally, the city planned to keep parking free for locals, but a federal grant requirement may force them to charge everyone.

What’s happening: City commissioners are finalizing a contract with PCI Municipal Services to install paid parking kiosks at the three parks. The plan would:

  • Charge $3 per hour, $20 per day, or $60 annually

  • Generate an estimated $900,000 per year, with $585,000 going to the city

  • Allow payment via kiosks or mobile app for added convenience

The city currently spends $303,000 annually on park maintenance, but officials say that’s not enough to keep up with repairs. Commissioner Michael Broderick put it bluntly:

💬 “Our general fund cannot continue to underwrite persons outside of our community using our assets for free.”

Why it matters:

  • 🚧 Park upkeep is expensive – Without a dedicated revenue stream, city officials say parks are deteriorating, and upgrades are needed.

  • 🏖️ The grant issue complicates things – The city originally promised free parking for locals, but a federal beach nourishment grant tied to Jetty Park requires equal access for all visitors.

  • 🚗 Businesses want more turnover – Limited parking on South Hutchinson Island means some visitors park all day, leaving no room for others. Paid parking could help with turnover.

What’s next: The commission hasn’t officially voted on the plan yet, but a majority supports moving forward with paid parking and an annual pass option. The final contract will be brought back for a vote soon.

💭 What do you think? Should Fort Pierce move forward with paid parking, or should locals get a free pass? Drop your thoughts here!

🍊 The Press Round: Fee Hike!

🏡 Fellsmere’s Population Set to Grow with 332 New Homes

The Marian Estates development will bring 150 townhomes and 182 single-family homes to Fellsmere, starting at $250K and $300K, respectively. While some welcome the growth, others worry about rising taxes and the loss of the city’s small-town feel.

👉 Read More

🗑️ St. Lucie County Tipping Fee Hike Could Raise Trash Collection Costs

The St. Lucie County Landfill has increased its tipping fees, meaning garbage collection costs will likely rise for Port St. Lucie residents unless the city finds an alternative. County officials say the rate hikes are necessary to keep the landfill financially sustainable.

👉 Read more

🚆 Martin County Rejects Quiet Zones for Train Horns

Martin County commissioners voted unanimously against implementing quiet zones, citing safety concerns after three rail-related deaths in the past decade. Officials say additional studies and safety measures would be needed before reconsidering.

👉 Read more

💰 Salary Status: City Goes Back and Forth

TL;DR: After weeks of back-and-forth, Fort Pierce’s pick for city manager, Richard Chess, has agreed to a 7.5% pay cut, now proposing a $200,000 starting salary with a potential 5% raise after six months. After not being okay with his intial asking price, commissioners are now split on whether this signals commitment or if Chess sees Fort Pierce as a stepping stone.

What’s happening:

  • Chess originally asked for $258,000, later dropping to $235,000—both figures exceeding the city’s advertised range.

  • In response to commission pushback, he’s now offering to start at $200,000, with a possible $10,000 raise after a six-month review.

  • For context: Chess currently makes $215,000 in Broward County, meaning this would be a pay cut.

💬 Commissioner Michael Broderick: “Why is he willing to go from $258,000 to $200,000 in a few conversations? Is this just a stepping stone?”

Not everyone is concerned. Commissioner Curtis Johnson Jr. sees this as a positive move:

💬 “It doesn’t trouble me… We have someone motivated to move Fort Pierce forward.”

Why it matters:

🏛️ Fort Pierce needs leadership – After former city manager Nick Mimms was fired amid a criminal investigation, the city has been in crisis mode. Commissioner James Taylor put it plainly:

💬 “We gotta get someone in here.”

💰 The salary still raises questions – Some worry about long-term commitment, while others say a motivated candidate willing to take a pay cut shouldn’t be overlooked.

What’s next: The final hiring decision is set for the March 17 commission meeting.

💭 What do you think? Should Fort Pierce move forward with Chess at $200K, or keep looking? Drop your thoughts here!

item.title: 🌅 🍀 St. Patrick’s Events, Café 772’s Return & A Special Tribute!
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: A heartfelt tribute, Café 772’s new location & St. Patty’s Day plans!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Afternoon, Sunland

It’s Tuesday! And… Mistakes happen—I’m definitely no stranger to them. But I’m grateful to have built enough trust with everyone here that when I do slip up, it’s not World War Z.

Yesterday was no exception—I mistakenly said that the Peacock House Art Foundation art tour was free… and it wasn’t. Apologies if you showed up expecting free entry!

I spoke with Emily (who was a pleasure to talk to) and went ahead and purchased 10 tickets, just in case someone arrived thinking it was free. Plus, all the proceeds go toward art supplies for kids, so I didn’t mind supporting a good cause. They have an interesting program that’s worth checking out!

While I wish I hadn’t made the oversight, I’m glad it turned into something positive.

Alright…

Ja’Min Devon

🍋 The Main Squeeze: 50 Years on the Road: A Tribute to My Grandmother, Martha Vickers

TL;DR: Last Friday, I got to witness something special—my grandmother, Martha Vickers, being honored for 50 years of service as a school bus driver in St. Lucie County. But this isn’t just a story about her. It’s about dedication, resilience, and what it means to show up every day for something bigger than yourself.

I got a call from my mom, Sherri Brown, last Tuesday asking, “What are you doing Friday morning around 8 AM?”

Nothing much, I told her.

“Well, you should come to the North Compound. Your grandmother is being honored for driving school buses for St. Lucie County for 50 years.”

I was there, of course—camera in hand, heart full.

At 4:00 AM Friday morning, like she has for decades, my grandmother got up for work. But this time, her final stop was different. At her last pickup, Superintendent Jon Prince stepped onto her bus to ride with her to the compound, where family, colleagues, school board members, and commissioners were waiting.

Flowers. Food. Applause. A celebration she absolutely deserved. She isn’t big on surprises, but I could tell—she felt the love. When asked why she’s still doing it after all these years, her answer was simple:

“I do it for the kids.”

At that moment, standing there with my camera, I realized this wasn’t just about her. It was a reflection of where I come from—a family built on service, commitment, and sticking it out even when things get tough.

In the room stood:

  • My cousin, Sylvester aka Lil Me, who drove school buses for St. Lucie County for 20+ years

  • My Aunt Mary (my Grandma’s twin sister), who has been driving for 41 years

  • My cousin, Iman, now a teacher in St. Lucie County

  • My mom, Sherri Brown, a 34-year educator

  • My Uncle Carnell, a St. Lucie County retired teacher.

And then there were the ones who couldn’t be there but still deserved to be mentioned:

  • My aunt, Mary Slater, a 34-year educator

  • My cousin, Eyvonda, an educator for nearly 20 years

  • My cousin, Shaunett, also an educator for decades

  • My grandfather, James Vickers, who drove school buses for St. Lucie County for 30+ years but is no longer with us

  • My uncle, Darin Slater, who was a pillar of the community, a barber for over 35 years, and the catalyst behind Sunland News

I’m sure I’m leaving out a BUNCH of people—my family group chat will let me know after they read this… But it really just came into view how important community and home is in my family and I look to keep that going!

And the celebration isn’t over. Tonight (Tuesday), my grandmother will be recognized at the St. Lucie County School Board meeting—something she’s been an active part of for years. If you’ve got time, come out and celebrate her. I’ll be there.

50 years speaks for itself. There are few things in life you can do that long without making a decision, early on, to stick it out—no matter what.

So, if you’re reading this and feeling stuck, uninspired, or unsure, just remember—commitment is its own kind of legacy.

This one’s for her. 💛

item.title: 🌅 🏫 St. Lucie’s New K-8 School, PSL’s Economy & What’s Next!
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: PLUS: Daylight Saving Time’s wild health effects, PSL’s slowing economy & a lunar eclipse!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Monday! If you’re just waking up or driving and noticing your clock says 6:27, but your phone says 7:27—don’t worry, you’re not losing it. We just lost an hour over the weekend.

Daylight saving time is here, which means less sleep and—oddly enough—a 24% spike in heart attacks the Monday after the time change. Meanwhile, in the fall, when we gain an hour, heart attacks drop by 21%.

Alright…

Ja’Min Devon

🍋 The Main Squeeze: St. Lucie County Expands Again with a New K-8 School

What’s going on: St. Lucie County is growing fast, and so are its schools. With Legacy High School set to open in Tradition this August, the county is already moving forward with its next big project—a brand-new K-8 school, set to open in August 2026.

What’s happening: The new K-8 school, located just a mile from Legacy High, will accommodate 1,900 students—a necessary expansion as schools across the county reach capacity.

💬 Superintendent Jon Prince: “We’re on such a fast construction track that we’ll be able to accommodate growth in real time.”

Why it matters: St. Lucie County’s population is booming, and with it, the need for more schools. The district has managed to move quickly and stay on budget by using an existing school model, reducing construction and architectural costs.

  • More K-8 schools are planned over the next five years, along with a new high school in the next seven years.

  • The district aims to make St. Lucie a “destination district”—a place where families feel confident sending their kids to school.

What’s next:

  • 🚜 Groundbreaking for the new K-8 school happens March 25

  • 🏫 The principal will be named in May

  • 📅 Doors open August 2026

💭 What do you think? Does St. Lucie County need even more schools, or is the district growing too fast? Drop your thoughts here!

📺 Watch the full story here.

🍊 The Press Round: 42 Years Strong!

💰 Indiantown at Risk of Losing Nearly $1M Due to Filing Delay

Indiantown officials are racing to file an overdue state financial report before the April 3 deadline, or risk losing $949,554 in county sales tax revenue. The delay, attributed to new technology installation and staffing limitations, also puts $190,000 in municipal sharing revenue temporarily at risk.

👉 Read more

🌕 Blood Moon Lunar Eclipse to Light Up Florida Skies

A total lunar eclipse will be visible across the Treasure Coast on March 13-14, marking the first eclipse event of the year. The blood moon will reach maximum totality at 2:58 a.m. and last over six hours before ending at 6 a.m.

👉 Read more

🦞 Conchy Joe’s: 42 Years of Seafood & Scenic Views

A Treasure Coast landmark, Conchy Joe’s has served up Old Florida hospitality for decades. My parents had their first date here, and the conch fritters + lobster bisque-clam chowder mix? Elite. WPTV just did a beautiful piece on the restaurant’s history and recent expansion.

👉 Read more

🌕 Poll: Are you staying up for the Blood Moon Eclipse?

The total lunar eclipse will be visible across the Treasure Coast on March 13-14, hitting peak totality at 2:58 a.m. and lasting over six hours.

💰 PSL’s Economy: A Breather, Not a Bust

TL;DR: Port St. Lucie’s economy is still strong, but things are slowing down—fewer building permits, a shift to a buyer’s market, and impact fees trending down. The good news? The city is using this moment to plan ahead.

🔑 What’s Happening:

  • Construction Slowdown: Fewer new homes and buildings going up compared to past years.

  • Real Estate Shift: No longer a seller’s market—buyers now have more leverage.

  • Budget Adjustments: Lower impact fees mean the city is tightening up spending, but key projects (roads, parks, and public safety) are still a priority.

💬 Why It Matters: A cooling economy gives PSL a chance to regroup, plan for the next wave of growth, and ensure infrastructure keeps up. With long-term plans in place until 2050, the city is focused on smart, sustainable development.

item.title: 🌅 💰 Fort Pierce’s City Manager Standoff—Is $235K Too Much?
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: A $38M armored vehicle facility, quail eggs & the city’s salary debate!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Friday! And we lose an hour of sleep this weekend—the dreaded Daylight Saving Time. Spring forward, if you will. I love a good debate, and usually, I’m pretty solid on picking a side. But this one? I can’t crack it. On one hand, I appreciate having a little more light in the evening when driving. On the other, it definitely takes some time to adjust.

Alright…

❓ Poll Question: Where do you stand on Daylight Saving Time? ⏰🌞

Vote & let me know why! 🚀

Ja’Min Devon

🍋 The Main Squeeze: Salary Stand Off, Fort Pierce City Manager Negotiations Hit a $35K Roadblock

TL;DR: Less than two weeks after selecting Richard D. Chess as their top choice for city manager, Fort Pierce commissioners are now at odds over his requested $235,000 salary—a figure that exceeds their advertised range and outpaces the former city manager’s pay by $33,000. Now, the question is: Can they reach a deal, or will the city be back to square one?

What’s happening: Chess, who currently makes $215,000 as assistant general manager of finance for Broward County Transportation, has made it clear he won’t take a pay cut to take the Fort Pierce job. His requested $235,000 salary is within the city’s posted range ($155,000-$230,000), but commissioners aren’t on board with exceeding the cap.

💬 Commissioner Arnold Gaines: “Who in their right mind would come up here and take a $20,000 pay cut?”

While most commissioners didn’t name an exact salary they’d approve, $235,000 was a hard no. The commission also expressed concern that a significant pay jump could trigger salary increases for other city staff in the future.

Why it matters:

  • Fort Pierce needs a city manager—especially one with financial expertise as budget planning season approaches.

  • Chess’ salary request isn’t unreasonable considering his experience and current pay, and Fort Pierce is a smaller city than Broward, not a cheaper one—he’d be moving 90 minutes north.

  • The former city manager, Nick Mimms, was making $202,000 after nine years before he was fired following his arrest for bid tampering and misconduct.

What’s next: Negotiations continue, with a March 17 vote set to determine Chess’ fate. If a deal isn’t struck, Fort Pierce may have to reopen its search, delaying leadership even further.

💭 Should the city meet Chess’ salary request, or is it time to move on? Drop your thoughts here!

item.title: 🌅 🚆 Brightline Battle, School Changes & Last Call for the Fair!
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: Brightline’s $60M station debate, St. Lucie’s newest high school & what’s next!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Morning, Sunland

It’s Wednesday! This is your weekly reminder to share the newsletter with a friend. The next big subscriber milestone? 5,000. We’re slowly ticking up, and honestly, I love that—slow growth means people who actually want to be here. So, as always, thank you for sharing!

✨ Shoutout: I came across a really cool story about Dan McCarty Middle School’s food pantry—which, first off, I didn’t even know they had! But more importantly, it’s great to see a resource like this for students, families, and the community. Love to see it.

Alright… let’s jump in!

🌡️ Weather Update: A stormy afternoon, but tonight’s looking chill

☀️ Day: High of 84°F | ⛈️ Windy with thunderstorms developing in the afternoon.
🌙 Night: Low of 54°F | 🌤️ Partly cloudy
🌅 Sunrise: 6:41 AM | 🌇 Sunset: 6:25 PM
🎵 Sounds like: “It Was a Good Day” by Ice Cube ☀️🎶

Ja’Min Devon

🍋 The Main Squeeze: The Battle Over the Brightline Station

TL;DR: Stuart and Martin County officials are set to meet Thursday at 1 p.m. in an attempt to resolve their dispute over who should pay for the $60 million Brightline station planned for downtown Stuart. If they can’t reach an agreement, this could head to court.

What’s happening: We thought the Brightline situation was settled back in November when Brightline and the county finally struck a deal to bring a station to Stuart—after the city backed out of its original agreement. Now, a lawsuit is imminent, and the whole thing is getting messy.

  • Stuart backed out of a property lease with Brightline in 2024, arguing the company should pay for half of the station costs.

  • Martin County moved forward on its own, securing a deal with Brightline to build the station on county-owned land.

  • Now, the county wants Stuart to provide a letter of support to help secure grant funding—but city officials are hesitant without guarantees on cost-sharing.

Why it matters: The station could be a game-changer for transportation and development in Stuart, but it comes down to who foots the bill. The city says the county’s deal doesn’t match what was originally agreed upon, while the county argues Stuart’s own growth plan supports a downtown train station.

What’s next: If a deal isn’t reached at Thursday’s meeting, a lawsuit could be next. Officials on both sides say they hope to avoid that outcome, but with millions at stake, neither seems willing to budge—yet.

💭 With all this back-and-forth, should Brightline consider other options? Should they bring a station to Fort Pierce instead? Drop your thoughts here!

🍊 The Press Round: Clock Strikes Later

👶 Treasure Coast May Lose More Prenatal Care Services

Florida Community Health Centers, which provided 27,299 prenatal visits last year, is considering closing clinics due to financial losses. This comes as Cleveland Clinic prepares to close its labor and delivery unit in Stuart and move services to Port St. Lucie.

👉 Read more

⏰ Florida Bill Could Change School Start Times Again

A proposed bill seeks to undo the 2026 law requiring later school start times for middle and high schools. Some educators worry about traffic congestion and logistical challenges, while others say the decision should be left to individual districts.

👉 Read more

🏠 Florida Bill Could Make Homeless Population Harder to Track

Experts say a new Florida law banning sleeping on public property is pushing the homeless into hiding, making it more difficult for agencies to conduct annual population counts—data that determines funding for housing and assistance programs.

👉 Read more

🧃 Refill: 🎓 A New Legacy Begins at
St. Lucie’s Newest High School

TL;DR: Legacy High School is now accepting students from any zone or county, a move that ensures the school has enough students and funding to operate effectively. Open enrollment runs through March 31.

📍 What’s New: St. Lucie Public Schools announced that Legacy High School, the county’s newest high school, is open to all students—regardless of their zoned school or county of residence. Out-of-zone and out-of-county students will need to provide their own transportation.

💬 Why It Matters: According to a district enrollment expert, this approach isn’t unique to Legacy—it’s common for newer high schools to expand enrollment early on to ensure they meet student population and funding requirements. Funding is crucial for schools and often hard to come by—just one shift in a program or enrollment numbers can mean thousands of dollars lost for any school. Fort Pierce Central has followed similar strategies to maintain stability.

📊 By the Numbers:

  • 1,500 students are expected in grades 9-11 during Legacy’s first year (2025-2026).

  • The first senior class will be introduced in 2026-2027.

⏳ What to Know:

  • Open enrollment is available until March 31.

  • Applications must be submitted via the district’s “Out of Zone” form (not the Universal Application).

Trivia Time! 🤔 How many students are enrolled in St. Lucie County’s public schools?

🐱 Friday Fest! Downtown Fort Pierce. Featuring TNVR cat rescue, Jack Sparrow photo ops, and fun surprises. | 5:30 PM–9 PM | Pop Out

Saturday, March 8

    The school board is considering selling naming rights to high school stadiums—Martin High could be first. Read More

item.title: 🌅 🎧 A Sunland Podcast? Plus, Meet the Pittman Boys!
item.description: ☀️🌱 PLUS: A football family launches a business, plus $2 fair night & music events!
item.dc:creator: Sunland News
item.content:encoded:
Good Afternoon, Sunland

It’s Tuesday! I’ve been playing with the idea of doing a podcast as a companion to this newsletter. It would just be once, maybe twice a week, but think of it as a quick 10 - 20 minute catch up of what’s going on. Would definately love to hear your thoughts on this idea… Alright. Let’s jump straight in!

Poll Question: Would you listen to a Sunland Podcast?

Ja’Min Devon

Support Sunland

🍋 The Main Squeeze
🏆 The Pittman Boys: More Than Just Athletes—They’re Building a Brand

TL;DR: Four brothers. One brand. A vision beyond football. The Pittman Boys—a tight-knit group of athletes from John Carroll High School—are launching their Pippin’ Boys clothing line this Saturday. What started as their father’s community work has grown into a full-fledged business with a mission: financial stability, giving back, and building something that lasts.

💬 Why It Matters: This isn’t just another merch drop. It’s young athletes thinking beyond the game, proving that entrepreneurship and sports can go hand in hand.

👕 From the Field to Fashion: The Pippin’ Boys brand traces back to their father’s efforts in the community—organizing events for kids and later selling Italian ice. Over time, that evolved into a clothing brand that represents their journey and ambition.

The Name & Colors: The brand name represents their bond as brothers, and their core colors—blue, black, and white—pay homage to their high school, John Carroll.

Bigger Than Merch: Their goal is to generate $10,000 annually—ensuring financial security long after their football careers end.

A Community Focus: Beyond making money, they want to give back to younger athletes and inspire kids to think about business at an early age.

🏈 Football First, But Not Forever: While their brand is a major focus, football is still the main priority for the Pittman Boys.

Each brother plays a different position, but they all push each other to be better.

Their dream schools include Oregon, Colorado, USF, and Houston—with a strong focus on programs that develop top talent.

Trash talk? A family tradition. One brother admits, “I talk to the other team’s sideline before I even return a kick.”

💡 The Business Mindset: When asked who’s the most business-savvy, the brothers couldn’t pick just one. It’s clear that entrepreneurship runs in the family—including their little sister, who already runs her own successful lemonade business.

“Best lemonade in the world, if you ask me.”

📅 What’s Next? The Pippin’ Boys brand officially launches this Saturday, with merch available for purchase. But this is just the beginning. Whether it’s in football, fashion, or business, the Pittman Boys are building something bigger than themselves.

👉 Want to support them? Keep an eye out for the official drop this weekend here.

If you have an event, send it to me here

🍹The Refill: 🎡 Your Fair Playbook: What’s Worth Checking Out?

It’s $2 Tuesday at the St. Lucie County Fair! That means $2 admission, $2 rides, and a whole lot of opportunity to dive into the best the fair has to offer—without breaking the bank. The fair isn’t here forever (only 10 days!), so if you’ve been waiting for the right moment to go, consider this your sign.

Rather than running down the full schedule, I figured I’d highlight a few things that caught my eye. Some are cool, some are unexpected, and some are just straight-up funny.

🎯 What’s Interesting at the Fair?

  •  Laser Tag at the Fair – Didn’t know this was a thing, but I’m intrigued. Carnival rides + laser tag? That’s a solid combo.

  • Mobile Arts Glass Blowing – Watching someone shape molten glass into art is oddly mesmerizing.

  • Steer Auction – Not in the market for a steer, but if you are, this might be your moment.

  • Small Animal Costume Parade – This is happening later in the week, but I needed to mention it. Tiny animals. In costumes. Enough said.

🎟️ The Basics

  • $2 Admission & Rides Today!

  • The fair wraps up this Sunday, so don’t wait too long!

📌 Want to see the full schedule? Check it out here.

🥛 Last Drop: 3 Things To Go!

  • 🏬 Indian River Mall: What’s Next?

    Nine months after new ownership, 67% of Indian River Mall remains empty—but tenants are hopeful about its future. Read More

  • 🏋️ New Supplement Shop in Downtown Fort Pierce

    Downtown Sports Nutrition just opened, offering workout supplements and wellness products—and they take requests! Their grand opening is this Saturday, March 8. Check It Out
